description: California Blackberries are easy to identify and can be found all over the bay area. When unripe the berries are bright pink/red and very hard, as they ripen the color will change to a dark black purple and they will soften to where you can easily crush them with your fingers. While these berries do ripen in warmer months it is recommended to wear long sleeves and pants when picking as they are covered in thorns. There are no poisonous look-alikes for blackberries, though there are several edible ones, such as raspberries, salmonberries, and thimbleberries.

There are no poisonous look-alikes for blackberries, though there are several edible ones, such as raspberries, salmonberries, and thimbleberries.

California Blackberries are easy to identify and can be found all over the bay area. When unripe the berries are bright pink/red and very hard, as they ripen the color will change to a dark black purple and they will soften to where you can easily crush them with your fingers. While these berries do ripen in warmer months it is recommended to wear long sleeves and pants when picking as they are covered in thorns. There are no poisonous look-alikes for blackberries, though there are several edible ones, such as raspberries, salmonberries, and thimbleberries.

Western Raspberries or Blackcap Raspberries are a lucky find in the bay area! They are generally darker and smaller than store bought raspberries and at times can appear completely purple. When unripe they will be incredibly difficult to remove from the plant and range from a light pink or yellow to vibrant red. While these berries do ripen in warmer months it is recommended to wear long sleeves and pants when picking as they are covered in thorns. There are no poisonous look-alikes  for western raspberries however, there are several edible look alikes including blackberries, salmonberries, and thimbleberries.

The Western Thimbleberry, like the salmonberry is also a member of the rose family. The easiest way to differentiate thimbleberries from any other similar berry is their leaves, most other look alikes have  leaves with three separate segments, where the thimbleberry has one solid leaf with five points. When unripe the thimbleberry is hard and a light dusty pink color. Be careful when hunting for thimbleberries as like their cousin the garden rose, they are covered in thorns.

The Whitestem Gooseberry has red and white flowers and shiny dark green leaves. It makes 3 to 6 ft tall open erect shrub. It likes full shade and moist areas, so it's often found on well shaded trails. The berries are bright green and hard when unripe and turn translucent and bouncy as they ripen. Other varieties have small spikes along the outside of berry, and range in color. These varieties are also edible, but tend to be cooked into jams and compotes.Their leaves are a medium green with 5 sections. Be careful when picking gooseberries, as they have very sharp thorns that tend to hide directly under the leaves.

The Whitestem Gooseberry has red and white flowers and shiny dark green leaves. It makes 3 to 6 ft tall open erect shrub. It likes full shade and moist areas, so it's often found on well shaded trails. The berries are bright green and hard when unripe and turn translucent and bouncy as they ripen. Other varieties have small spikes along the outside of berry, and range in color. These varieties are also edible, but tend to be cooked into jams and compotes.Their leaves are a medium green with 5 sections. Be careful when picking gooseberries, as they have very sharp thorns that tend to hide directly under the leaves.

Salmon berries are a member of the rose family, and when blooming this is obvious. The salmonberry has a  beautiful five petal bloom that ranges in color from light pink to a bright magenta. Unlike other similar berries the salmon berry has a range of colors when ripe from bright yellow/tangerine to a dark red/purple. The easiest way to tell if a salmon berry is ripe is by simply trying to remove it from the plant, if it comes off with. little to no effort, its ripe! Be careful when foraging for salmon berries, as like garden roses, they are covered in thorns. There are no poisonous look-alikes  for salmon berries however, there are several edible look alikes including blackberries, raspberries, and thimbleberries.

Huckleberry's are a prized find in the North Bay. While the bushes can be found on almost any trail, they don't often have fruit, as you're competing with birds, insects, and other foragers! They can easily be identified by their red tinted branches and thick almond-shaped spiky leaves. When unripe the berries will be a medium green, darkening to a black/blue as they ripen. The berries resemble a slightly long blueberry. If you find this treat in the woods stock up as they make great jams, pies, and other deserts.

I would give more information, but honestly if you can't identify an apple, you probably should not be foraging.

Chicken of the woods can often turn a flop of a mushroom hunt into a wild success. They grow out of live but decaying trees and can be found up to 100lbs! Their unique shape and color make them one of the easiest mushrooms to identify. They grow in ruffled sheets on the sides and bottoms of trees in large clusters. Their bright orange and yellow color make them easy to spot, and when cooked have almost the exact same texture as chicken, hence the name. REMINDER - NEVER EAT A MUSHROOM THAT YOU CANNOT IDENTIFY WITH 100% ACCURACY.

The California King Bolete is a real prize in the foraging world! Larger mushrooms are usually dried and used in soups, while younger smaller mushrooms can be eaten raw, or cooked. Bolettes have a reddish-brown cap with tan pores instead of gills underneath. They can often be found  under conifers (pine, western hemlock, Sitka spruce) and hardwoods (oak, birch, aspen). REMINDER - NEVER EAT A MUSHROOM THAT YOU CANNOT IDENTIFY WITH 100% ACCURACY.

Bull Kelp can be used in many different ways, from pickles to soup! While this is one of my personal favorite kelps, I don't recommend picking bull kelp as they are an essential part of California's kelp forests that are currently being devastated by a boom in sea urchins. I only condone eating Bull Kelp that has recently washed ashore. It can be easily identified as the shape looks like a large whip, with a bulbous end and long flat leaves.

Kombu is one of the most well known kelps, and one of the most popular. It can be identified by its long flat blade with a puckered sometimes bumpy texture. Kombu is used mostly for adding umami flavor to dishes, and is an essential part of making dashi, a Japanese stock. When harvesting Kombu be sure to pick with a pair of scissors and not by ripping the plant from the base. This ensures that the plant can regrow after harvesting from it.

Wakame is a delicious seaweed that can be used in soups, or as a vegetable. It can be identified by its large, thin blade with flat midrib. It may be torn on edges or ends and appear ruffly. With seaweed, bringing reference photos for identification is essential as there are so many varieties that grow in small spaces.

Sea Lettuce is one of the few seaweeds eaten primarily raw! Its bright green color and ruffled texture makes it pop out in rocky seashores. Sea lettuce can also be dried and used as a rice topping or to add umami to any dish. It can be found on rocky shores below the low tide line. When harvesting, be sure to use scissors instead of ripping the plant from the base. This insures the plant will be able to regrow after harvest.

Plum foraging in the Bay area is one of the easiest to identify. The plums can range in size from the size of a cherry to slightly smaller than a store bought plum. Plums here are often planted as ornamental trees, meaning you can find them anywhere from a hiking trail to a safeway parking lot! They have a range of colors including black, bright purple, orange, and pale yellow. The best rule of thumb when it comes to identifying plums in the wild is, if it looks like a plum, and it smells like a plum, it's a plum. Never eat the pit!

While Figs aren't native to the Bay area, you wouldn't know it by their prevalence and ability to thrive here. Figs can be identified by their large slightly textured leaves with 3 to five distinct lobes. Figs range in color from green to dark purple, making it sometimes difficult to tell when a fig is ripe. The easiest way to tell if a fig is ripe is by how easily its picked, if you have to yank it off the bush, then it probably isn't ready.
